get.description: Start authorization_code flows by requesting consent to act on behalf of the user. If the user is not logged in, they will be prompted to log in first. Upon successful consent, the user will be redirected back to the client application, as specified in the redirect_uri parameter.

client_id.description: The unique identifier for the OAuth2 client.

redirect_uri.description: The URL to redirect to after authorization. Must match one of the redirect URIs registered for the client.

response_type.description: Specifies the OAuth2 response type. This is mandatory for all authentication flows.

code_challenge.description: The code challenge used in the Authorization Code with PKCE flow.

code_challenge_method.description: The code challenge method used in the Authorization Code with PKCE flow.

state.description: An opaque value used by the client to maintain state between the request and callback. The authorization server includes this value when redirecting the user-agent back to the client.

nonce.description: A random value used to mitigate replay attacks. Similar to state, but used for id token validation if needed.

scope.description: A space-separated list of scopes that define the permissions. Use 'openid' to obtain id token for openid support. Use 'offline_access' to obtain a refresh token.

302.description: Redirects user to the consent page with requested oauth scope and state. Upon successful consent, user will be redirected back to the client application providing authorization code and state in the following format: **https://redirecturl.ofmyapp.com/?code={authorization-code}&state={state}**.

post.description: Exchange authorization code, refresh token, or client credentials for an access token.

schema.description: The required parameters depend on the grant type.

grant_type.description: Specifies the OAuth2 grant type. This is mandatory for all authentication flows.

client_id.description: The unique identifier for the OAuth2 client. Required for all grant types.

client_secret.description: The secret key for the OAuth2 client. Not required with PKCE or with client_assertion.

client_assertion_type.description: The type of client assertion. Applicable only for the client_credentials grant type.

client_assertion.description:
The client assertion jwt token. Applicable only for the client_credentials grant type. If provided, client_secret is not needed.
            The issuer and subject must be the oauth2 client_id, and the audience must be the base url of token endpoint. Token can be valid only for 1 minute.

code.description: The authorization code. Required and applicable only for the authorization_code grant type.

code_verifier.description: The code verifier used in the Authorization Code with PKCE flow.

refresh_token.description: The token used to obtain a new access token when the current one expires. Required and applicable only for the refresh_token grant type.

scope.description: A space-separated list of scopes that define the permissions. Required and applicable only for the client_credentials grant type.

delegated_user_id.description: Impersonated user's id in client_credentials flow, allowing the API to act on behalf of this user. Required and applicable only for the client_credentials grant type.

access_token.description: The access token to use for API requests.

expires_in.description: The number of seconds until the token expires.

scope.description: The scopes granted by the user, separated by space.

refresh_token.description: The refresh token to generate new access tokens after authorization_code flows. Returned only if offline_access scope is requested.

id_token.description: OpenId JWT that contains authenticated user's profile data. Returned only if openid scope is requested.

post.description: Revoke a refresh token to invalidate it and prevent its use in future requests. Existing access tokens authorized by the refresh token will remain valid until their expiry.

client_id.description: The unique identifier for the OAuth2 client.

client_secret.description: The secret key for the OAuth2 client.

get.description: List all enums in a tree structure

200.description: Returns the nested App → DataSource → Field → Enum structure

post.description: Receives a list of documents and initiates the SharePoint migration process.
post.summary: Migrate static DM data to SharePoint

404.description: Notification not found or access denied
Notification not found or access denied

200.description: All notifications marked as read successfully

info.title: Docyrus REST API
info.description:
# Authorization

The Docyrus API uses **OAuth 2.0** and **Bearer tokens** for api access. Supported grant types include **client credentials** and **authorization code**.
You can use **client credentials** flow for single user, server-to-server communication; and **authorization code** flow to request access on behalf of users with their consents.
In both cases, you need to obtain an access token to make authenticated requests to the API.

[**PKCE**](https://oauth.net/2/pkce/) extension for the authorization code flow is supported, which enhances security by eliminating the need to store client secrets and protecting against authorization code interception attacks.

Client credentials can be sent as separate parameters or as base64 encoded basic auth token in the Authorization header. Client authentication is also supported using JWT assertion token ["urn:ietf:params:oauth:client-assertion-type:jwt-bearer"](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7523#section-2.2).

Docyrus also supports [**OpenID Connect**](https://api.docyrus.com/.well-known/openid-configuration) over OAuth 2.0. You can implement single sign-on (SSO) with id tokens to authenticate users and get their profile information.
You can obtain id tokens by requesting "openid" scope. Then you can use [discovery endpoint](https://api.docyrus.com/.well-known/jwks.json) to get the public keys and verify the id tokens. 
We recommend caching the public keys by "kid" values to avoid hitting rate limits.

---

# Request & Response

## Request Headers

| Header Name                | Description                        |
|----------------------------|------------------------------------|
| Content-Type               | application/json                   |
| Authorization              | Bearer <access_token>              |

## Response Format

200 OK, 201 Created:

```json
{
  "success": true,
  "data": array | object,
  "meta": object // may not be present
}
```

Error Response:

```json
{
  "success": false,
  "error": string, // one of the error codes below,
  "error_description": string
}
```

## Common Response Codes

| Response Code | Description                                                   |
|---------------|---------------------------------------------------------------|
| 200 OK        | Successful requests that don't match any other response code. |
| 201 Created   | Resource created successfully.                                |
| 204 No Content| Successful request with no response body.                     |
| 405 Method Not Allowed | Invalid HTTP method.                                 |
| 500 Internal Server Error | An unexpected or undefined error occurred.        |

## Common Error Codes

| Error Code                  | Default Message                                                                 | Status Code |
|-----------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------|
| invalid_resource            | The requested resource is not found.                                            | 404         |
| rate_limit_exceeded         | Number of requests exceeded the rate limit.                                     | 400         |
| access_denied               | User denied access to the client app.                                           | 403         |
| insufficient_scope          | The request requires higher privileges than provided by the access token.       | 403         |
| invalid_client_id           | Client identifier is missing or invalid.                                        | 401         |
| invalid_client_credentials  | Client secret is missing or invalid.                                            | 401         |
| invalid_assertion_type      | Specified assertion type isn’t supported.                                       | 400         |
| invalid_grant               | (Custom message required)                                                       | 400         |
| invalid_token               | Token is invalid.                                                               | 401         |
| invalid_request             | (Custom message required)                                                       | 400         |
| invalid_scope               | The requested scope is invalid.                                                 | 400         |
| redirect_uri_mismatch       | Redirect URI must match the authorized URIs.                                    | 400         |
| unsupported_response_type   | Response type is unsupported.                                                   | 400         |
| unsupported_grant_type      | Grant type is unsupported.                                                      | 400         |


# Scopes

| Scope                  | Description                                                                  |
|------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| openid                 | Identify the user with OpenID Connect information                            |
| offline_access         | Access resources on behalf of the user even when they are offline            |
| Read.All               | View all available resources                                                 |
| ReadWrite.All          | View and modify all available resources                                      |
| Users.Read             | View the signed-in user's profile                                            |
| Users.ReadWrite        | View and modify the signed-in user's profile                                 |
| Users.Read.All         | View profiles of all users                                                   |
| Users.ReadWrite.All    | View and modify profiles of all users                                        |
| DS.Read.All            | View all data sources                                                        |
| DS.ReadWrite.All       | View and modify all data sources                                             |
| DS.Read.{{Slug}}       | View data from the specified data source ({{Slug}})                          |
| DS.ReadWrite.{{Slug}}  | View and modify data from the specified data source ({{Slug}})               |

---

# Quick Start

1. **Create OAuth2 Client**: Go to "developers" section to create your api application and oauth2.0 client credentials (**client_id** and **client_secret**).
2. **Obtain an Access Token**: Determine which grant type to use based on your use case and obtain an access token using authorization endpoints.
3. **Send Authorized Requests**: Make sure you include "Authorization: Bearer <YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN>" in every subsequent authorized request.
4. **Handle Token Expiry**: Tokens have a limited lifetime. Use refresh tokens (authorization code flow) or client credentials to obtain new access tokens when they expire. The expiry time is 1 hour for access tokens and 1 month for refresh tokens, but it is subject to change in the future. Make sure to handle token expiry gracefully. The authorization endpoints are throttled, so avoid requesting new tokens too frequently.

# Next Steps

- **Explore each endpoint** in detail, including path parameters, query parameters, and request bodies. You can use the interactive API documentation to test each endpoint.
- **Implement robust error handling** to handle various response codes, especially token errors.
- **Rate limit your requests** to ensure optimal performance and prevent getting errors. Each tenant is subject to a default rate limit of 240 requests per minute. 
Implement efficient algorithms to manage request rates and avoid exceeding these limits. Note that rate limits may vary and are subject to change.

For further details, please refer to the full OpenAPI specification or reach out to [Docyrus Support](mailto://support@docyrus.com) for any questions regarding your integration.

---

**Happy Coding with Docyrus!**

Columns.name: columns
Columns.description:
List of columns.

Each column can be specified by its name or as an array of expanded columns inside parentheses. They can also take aliases by using the ":" character.

**Example**: Suppose that you have "account" records, and "contact" records for each account connecting through "related_account" column. You can use following column syntax to get account and contact data together:

**Fetch given columns as they are:**

  ```
  ["firstname","lastname","related_account"]` 
  =>
  { firstname: "...", lastname: "...", related_account: { "id": "..." } }
  ```

**Fetch related account columns:**

  ```
  ["firstname","lastname","related_account(name,phone)"]
  =>
  { firstname: "...", lastname: "...", related_account: { "name": "...", "phone": "..." } }
  ```

**Use aliases:**

  ```
  ["f:firstname","l:lastname","a:related_account(name,phone)"]
  =>
  { f: "...", l: "...", a: { "name": "...", "phone": "..." } }
  ```

**Use spread operator:** 

  ```
  ["firstname","lastname","...related_account(accountName:name,accountPhone:phone)"]
  =>
  { firstname: "...", lastname: "...", "accountName": "...", "accountPhone": "..." }
  ```

DistinctColumns.name: distinctColumns
DistinctColumns.description: List of distinct columns in order to deduplicate data. Should be avoided unless it is strictly necessary for performance reasons.

Rows.name: rows
Rows.description: List of columns for second axis. Used for pivotal queries.

Calculations.description: List of calculation objects to aggregate data.
